Publications

Selected publications

  • MedSafetyBench – Evaluating and Improving the Medical Safety of Large Language Models
    Tessa Han, Aounon Kumar, Chirag Agarwal, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), Datasets and Benchmarks, 2024
    summary How do we define, evaluate, and improve the medical safety of large language models (LLMs)? In this paper, we define the notion of medical safety for LLMs, develop a novel benchmark dataset (MedSafetyBench) to assess it, and evaluate and improve the medical safety of medical LLMs. We find that 1) current medical LLMs do not meet standards of general or medical safety and that 2) fine-tuning these medical LLMs using our benchmark dataset significantly improves their safety. / paper / code / dataset

  • Characterizing Data Point Vulnerability via Average-Case Robustness
    Tessa Han*, Suraj Srinivas*, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI), 2024
    summary How do we efficiently characterize a data point's vulnerability using average-case robustness? In this paper, we 1) derive efficient analytical estimators, 2) validate their accuracy and efficiency through theoretical and empirical analyses, and 3) demonstrate their usefulness for various tasks involving average-case robustness (e.g., measuring class-level robustness bias and identifying dataset samples that are vulnerable to noise perturbation). / paper / code

  • Which Explanation Should I Choose? A Function Approximation Perspective to Characterizing Post Hoc Explanations
    Tessa Han, Suraj Srinivas, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), 2022
    summary What are the basic properties of post hoc explanation methods and when is each method effective? In this paper, we 1) formalize the local function approximation framework, unifying eight diverse, popular explanation methods; 2) demonstrate that no method can perform optimally in every situation via the no free lunch theorem, calling for a principled approach to selecting among methods; and 3) set forth a guiding principle based on faithful function approximation to guide the selection among existing explanation methods and the design of novel ones. / paper / code
    >> Best Paper Award, ICML Workshop on Interpretable ML for Healthcare (IMLH), 2022

All publications and preprints

  • (preprint) Building Bridges, Not Walls – Advancing Interpretability by Unifying Feature, Data, and Model Component Attribution
    Shichang Zhang, Tessa Han*, Usha Bhalla*, and Hima Lakkaraju
    summary In intepretability research, the areas of feature, data, and component attribution tend to be studied and applied rather independently, resulting in a fragmented research landscape. In this position paper, we argue that 1) these three areas share fundamental similarities, employing common approaches and differing mainly in perspective rather than core techniques, and that 2) this more unified view can advance not only interpretability research, by stimulating cross-domain knowledge transfer, but also broader AI research, by improving model editing, steering, and regulation. / paper

  • MedSafetyBench – Evaluating and Improving the Medical Safety of Large Language Models
    Tessa Han, Aounon Kumar, Chirag Agarwal, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), Datasets and Benchmarks, 2024
    summary How do we define, evaluate, and improve the medical safety of large language models (LLMs)? In this paper, we define the notion of medical safety for LLMs, develop a novel benchmark dataset (MedSafetyBench) to assess it, and evaluate and improve the medical safety of medical LLMs. We find that 1) current medical LLMs do not meet standards of general or medical safety and that 2) fine-tuning these medical LLMs using our benchmark dataset significantly improves their safety. / paper / code / dataset

  • Characterizing Data Point Vulnerability via Average-Case Robustness
    Tessa Han*, Suraj Srinivas*, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI), 2024
    summary How do we efficiently characterize a data point's vulnerability using average-case robustness? In this paper, we 1) derive efficient analytical estimators, 2) validate their accuracy and efficiency through theoretical and empirical analyses, and 3) demonstrate their usefulness for various tasks involving average-case robustness (e.g., measuring class-level robustness bias and identifying dataset samples that are vulnerable to noise perturbation). / paper / code

  • Which Explanation Should I Choose? A Function Approximation Perspective to Characterizing Post Hoc Explanations
    Tessa Han, Suraj Srinivas, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), 2022
    summary What are the basic properties of post hoc explanation methods and when is each method effective? In this paper, we 1) formalize the local function approximation framework, unifying eight diverse, popular explanation methods; 2) demonstrate that no method can perform optimally in every situation via the no free lunch theorem, calling for a principled approach to selecting among methods; and 3) set forth a guiding principle based on faithful function approximation to guide the selection among existing explanation methods and the design of novel ones. / paper / code
    >> Best Paper Award, ICML Workshop on Interpretable ML for Healthcare (IMLH), 2022

  • The Disagreement Problem in Explainable Machine Learning – A Practitioner’s Perspective
    Satyapriya Krishna*, Tessa Han*, Alex Gu, Javin Pombra, Shahin Jabbari, Steven Wu, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Transactions on Machine Learning Research (TMLR), 2024
    summary To what extent do explanations from post hoc explanation methods agree and how are disagreeing explanations resolved in practice? In this paper, we introduce and systematically study the “disagreement problem” in explainable machine learning. We find that 1) existing explanation methods often generate disagreeing explanations and 2) practitioners do not have a principled approach to selecting among disagreeing explanations, resorting to ad hoc heuristics such as personal preference. / paper
    >> Media coverage - Featured in Fortune (Article 1 and Article 2) and Analytics India Magazine (Article)

  • Is Ignorance Bliss? Investigating How Faithfulness and Alignment of Post Hoc Explanations Affect Model Trust in Laypeople and Domain Experts
    Tessa Han*, Yasha Ektefaie*, Maha Farhat, Marinka Zitnik, and Hima Lakkaraju
    Machine Learning for Health Symposium (ML4H), 2023
    summary What factors affect laypeople and domain experts' trust in post hoc explanations? In this paper, we find that while laypeople base their trust on explanation faithfulness, domain experts (incorrectly) base theirs on explanation alignment, suggesting a cognitive bias among domain experts. / paper

  • Hevelius Report – Visualizing Web-Based Motility Test Data for Clinical Decision and Learning Support
    Hongjin Lin, Tessa Han, Krzysztof Gajos, and Anoopum Gupta
    ACM SIGACCESS Conference on Computers and Accessibility (ASSETS), 2024
    summary How do we measure, visualize, and interpret the mobility of patients with Parkinson's or ataxia over time? In this work, we develop Hevelius Report, a visualization tool to track the mobility of these patients, and demonstrate its utility. / paper

  • Python and R packages for Interactive Visualization of Spatial Single-Cell Omics Data
    Mark Keller, Trevor Manz, Tessa Han, Ilan Gold, Chuck McCallum, and Nils Gehlenborg
    Conference on Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology and European Conference on Computational Biology (ISMB/ECCB), 2021
    summary How do we effectively integrate and visualize high-dimensional, multimodal, spatial data in single-cell genomics? In this paper, to enable these visualizations, we develop Vitessce (Visual integration tool for exploration of spatial single cell experiments), a web-based, interactive visualization tool. We also develop associated Python, R/RStudio, and RShiny tools to enable using Vitessce within the Python and R bioinformatics ecosystems. / paper
    Tools: Vitessce + code / Python package + code / R package + code / R Shiny + code

  • Genome-Wide Somatic Alterations in Multiple Myeloma Reveal a Superior Outcome Group
    Mehmet Kemal Samur, Anil Aktas Samur, Mariateresa Fulciniti, Raphael Szalat, Tessa Han, Masood Shammas, Paul Richardson, Florence Magrangeas, Stephane Minvielle, Jill Corre, Philippe Moreau, Anjan Thakurta, Kenneth Anderson, Giovanni Parmigiani, Hervé Avet-Loiseau, and Nikhil Munshi
    Journal of Clinical Oncology, 2020
    summary What is the genomic landscape of multiple myeloma and what are the genomic markers associated long-term survival? In this paper, we characterize the genomic landscape of multiple myeloma using deep whole-genome sequencing data. We find mutational signatures that reveal mechanisms of progression and variability in mutational load among known subgroups. In addition, we identify a new, genomically-defined subgroup (characterized by lower mutational load, age-related mutations, and the NRAS mutation) with prolonged overall and progression-free survival. / paper

  • Dysregulated miRNAs after Uniform Treatment Predict Outcome of Newly-Diagnosed Multiple Myeloma
    Tessa Han, Stephane Minvielle, Anil Aktas Samur, Mariateresa Fulciniti, Florence Magrangeas, Paul Richardson, Philippe Moreau, Michel Attal, Kenneth Anderson, Hervé Avet-Loiseau, Giovanni Parmigiani, Mehmet Kemal Samur, and Nikhil Munshi
    Blood (Supplemental Issue), 2019
    summary What is the role of miRNAs in the prognosis and progression of multiple myeloma? Here, we find that dysregulated miRNAs are predictive of disease prognosis in newly-diagnosed multiple myeloma patients and may contribute to disease progression by targeting key multiple myeloma genes (including MAF, BCL2, 14-3-3 and MYEOV). / paper (abstract)
    >> Abstract Achievement Award, American Society of Hematology, 2019

  • The Landscape of Genome-Wide Somatic Alterations Identifies a Good-Risk Group in Newly-Diagnosed Multiple Myeloma
    Mehmet Kemal Samur, Anil Aktas Samur, Tessa Han, Marco Roncador, Mariateresa Fulciniti, Raphael Szalat, Masood Shammas, Jill Corre, Paul Richardson, Florence Magrangeas, Stephane Minvielle, Philippe Moreau, Michel Attal, Anjan Thakurta, Kenneth Anderson, Giovanni Parmigiani, Hervé Avet-Loiseau, and Nikhil Munshi
    Blood (Supplemental Issue), 2019
    summary At the genomic level, what distinguishes low-risk (long-survival) multiple myeloma patients from high-risk (short-survival) multiple myeloma patients? Here, we analyze whole-genome and whole-transcriptome sequencing data from multiple myeloma patients and identify a new low-risk subgroup in which chromosome and telomere maintenance pathways and genes associated with low bone disease are upregulated, processes associated with DNA damage are downregulated, and there are lower mutation rates for known oncogenes and tumor suppressors (e.g. TP53, CSMD1, and FAT3/FAT4). / paper (abstract)
